Holly Cole Pop Singer Fez at the Time Cafe

With her clear, bright voice, eclectic taste that runs from country to jazz, and an approach to a song that is often brashly ironic, Holly Cole is a pop-jazz singer with a distinctly contemporary point of view.

Ms. Cole, who appeared with her trio on Tuesday and Wednesday, is a big star in Canada but only a cult figure in the United States, where she has released two albums. All it would take to establish her here is one medium-size hit.

On Tuesday evening, Ms. Cole and her musical partners, Aaron Davis on piano and David Piltch on bass, gave a concert that was by turns funny, elegant, bawdy and touching. Although Ms. Cole and her colleagues call themselves a trio, they lean more toward pop than toward jazz. Ms. Cole, who suggests a vocal hybrid of Bette Midler and Phoebe Snow, rarely improvises. Her strong, declarative approach is more concerned with interpreting lyrics than with rhythmic subtlety.

Clad in an evening dress and long black gloves, Ms. Cole affected a funky elegance that was mirrored in her choice of material and in her smart stage patter. A sassy, uptempo version of "On a Slow Boat to China" was introduced as a song about "unadulterated lust on the ocean." "Everything I Have" was dedicated to "our old friends the Bobbitts." The vintage Doris Day hit "Que Sera, Sera" was transformed from an expression of girlish optimism into a bluesy song of ironic resignation.

Deeply suspicious of pop's romantic platitudes, Ms. Cole introduced "If I Were a Bell" as the only song in her arsenal with "a real-life Hollywood ending," then delivered guttural Louis Armstrong-style "ding-dongs" that undercut its giddiness with a raw, comic sensuality. STEPHEN HOLDEN
